statement.p:
Let n be a positive integer. Find a general formula for S(n,2), the number of ways to partition the set [n] into two blocks.
Pick any nonempty and proper subset \emptyset \subsetneq S \subsetneq [n]. The set S and its complement \overline{S} form a partition of [n] into two (nonempty) blocks. There are 2^n -2 ways to choose S.
However, this process creates each set partition twice because choosing S leads to the same set partition as choosing its complement \overline{S}. So we must divide by 2 to obtain our final answer. We have
S(n,2) = \frac{2^n-2}{2} = 2^{n-1} -1.

exercise.title: The Next Row of the Stirling Triangle

idx.h: The Next Row of the Stirling Triangle

statement.p:
Use the Stirling Recurrence
S(n,k) = S(n-1, k-1) + S(n-1,k)
to find the n=6 row of the Stirling triangle.
The values S(6,0)=0 (impossible) and S(6,1)=1 and S(6,6)=1 are clear from the definition. We use the recurrence to find the remaining values
\begin{array}{rcl} S(6,0) &=& 0 \\ S(6,1) &=& 1 \\ S(6,2) &=& S(5,1) + 2 \cdot S(5,2) = 1 + 2 \cdot 15 = 31\\ S(6,3) &=& S(5,2) + 3 \cdot S(5,3) = 15 + 3 \cdot 25 = 90\\ S(6,4) &=& S(5,3) + 4 \cdot S(5,4) = 25 + 4 \cdot 10 = 65 \\ S(6,5) &=& S(5,4) + 5 \cdot S(5,5) = 10 + 5 \cdot 1 = 15\\ S(6,6) &=& 1 \\ \end{array}
So the next row is
\begin{array}{ccccccc} 0 & 1 & 31 & 90 & 65 & 15 & 1 \end{array}

What balls-in-boxes problem is equivalent to partitions of [n] into k parts? There are four decisions to make about the balls and boxes.
distinct balls
identical boxes
repetition allowed
no box can be empty

Stirling numbers of the second kind satisfy the following identity \[ S(n+1,k) = \sum_{i=0}^n { n \choose i} S(n-i, k-1). \]
Use the Stirling triangle we made in class to verify the identity is true for n=4 and k=3. Note that S(n,0)=0 and S(n,k)=0 when k>n.
\begin{eqnarray*} S(5,3) &=& {4 \choose 0} S(4,2) + {4 \choose 1} S(3,2) + {4 \choose 2} S(2,2) + {4 \choose 3} S(1,2) + {4 \choose 4} S(0,2) \\ &=& 1 \cdot 7 + 4 \cdot 3 + 6 \cdot 1 + 4 \cdot 0 + 1 \cdot 0 \, = \, 25. \end{eqnarray*}
Give a combinatorial proof of the identity. That is, explain why the LHS and the RHS count the exact same thing.
LHS: The number of ways to partition [n+1] into k parts.
RHS: Counts the same set, grouping the partitions according to the number of elements of [n] that occur in the set with element n+1.
Fix i. We count the number of partitions of [n+1] where the element n+1 is in a set with i elements. We choose our set in two phases.
Phase 1: Choose the i elements to appear in the set with element n+1. This can be done in {n \choose i} ways.
Phase 2: Partition the remaining n-i elements into k-1 sets. This can be done in S(n-i,k-1)
Now we sum over all possible values of i, namely 0 \leq i \leq n.

Consider the set {\cal F} of all functions f : [n] \rightarrow [k]. For each subset of {\cal F} below, determine (i) which balls-in-boxes problem is equivalent to the subset (ii) any restrictions on n and k, and (iii) the formula for the size of the set (if we know it).
The set of all functions f: [n] \rightarrow [k]
distinct balls
distinct boxes
repetition allowed
boxes can be empty
Number of ways: k^n, with no restrictions on n and k.
The set of injections f: [n] \rightarrow [k]
distinct balls
distinct boxes
repetition not allowed
boxes can be empty
Number of ways: (k)_n and we must have k \geq n.
The set of surjections f: [n] \rightarrow [k]
distinct balls
distinct boxes
repetition allowed
boxes cannot be empty
Number of ways: k! \cdot S(n,k) (see if you can explain why!) and we must have k \leq n.
The set of bijections f: [n] \rightarrow [k]
distinct balls
distinct boxes
repetition not allowed
boxes cannot be empty
Number of ways: k! and we must have k = n.

exercise.title: Writing x^n as a combination of (x)_k's

idx.h: Writing x^n as a combination of (x)_k's

statement.p:
In this problem, you will prove the following cool formula for n \geq 0:
x^n = \sum_{k=0}^n S(n,k) (x)_k.
Recall that the set \R[x] of (finite) polynomials in x form a vector space over \R. Our typical basis for \R[x] is:
1, x, x^2, \ldots, x^k, \ldots.
Explain why another basis for \R[x] is:
1, (x)_1, (x)_2, (x)_3, \ldots, (x)_k, \ldots.
Just give an intuitive explanation (not a rigorous proof).
The set of falling factorial polynomials are:
\begin{array}{ccccc} 1, & (x)_1 = x, &(x)_2 = x(x-1)= x^2 - x, & (x)_3 = x(x-1)(x-2) = x^3 -3x^2 + 2x, & \ldots \end{array}
For each k \geq 0, we have one polynomial of degree k. So this will end up being a basis of \R[x].
Give a combinatorial proof that
m^n = \sum_{k=0}^n S(n,k) (m)_k.
In particular, both sides count the number of ways to assign n students to m classrooms where some classrooms can be empty. Explain.
RHS:
Each of the n students has her choice of m classrooms. So the total number of ways is m^n.
LHS:
First, pick the number k of classrooms that will be used
Next, split the students into k nonempty groups. This can be done in S(n,k) ways.
Now, assign each group to a different classroom. This can be done in (m)_k ways.
Fixing n, now consider the polynomial equation
x^n - \sum_{k=0}^n S(n,k) (x)_k= 0.
Explain why part (b) shows that this equation has an infinite number of solutions. Then conclude that the LHS must in fact be the zero polynomial, so
x^n = \sum_{k=0}^n S(n,k) (x)_k.
Let p(x) = \displaystyle{x^n - \sum_{k=0}^n S(n,k) (x)_k}. Part (b) says that p(x)= 0 for x=1,2,3, \ldots, m, \ldots. In other words, this polynomial has an infinite number roots. The only such polynomial is the zero polynomial. Therefore,
x^n = \sum_{k=0}^n S(n,k) (x)_k.
Our conclusion is: when the polynomial x^n is expressed in terms of the falling factorial basis 1, (x)_1, (x)_2, (x)_3, \ldots, (x)_k, \ldots, then the coefficient for basis element (x)_k is S(n,k).
